document.masterDocTitle: Redescription of Brachyolus punctatus White, 1846 (Coleoptera: Curculionidae: Entiminae), with synonyms and lectotype designations

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Redescription of Brachyolus punctatus White, 1846 (Coleoptera: Curculionidae: Entiminae), with synonyms and lectotype designations

subSubSection.paragraph: Holotype ( Figures 13, 14 ). Female ( BMNH ). Glued to card mount; specimen entire. Labelled: ‘2386.’ [handwritten, Broun’s hand; off-white rectangular card], ‘Stratford’ [printed, off-white rectangular card], BCBM label, ‘ Brachyolus / viridescens’ [handwritten, Broun’s hand; off-white rectangular card], ‘ BMNH (E) / 1237380’ [printed, white rectangular label], ‘ HOLOTYPE / Brachyolus / viridescens / Broun 1893 / Confirmed SDJ Brown 2013’ [printed, red rectangular label].
Broun (1893) explicitly states that only one specimen from Stratford made up the type series, thereby implicitly designating a holotype.
19 Other material examined: A total of 303 specimens examined ( 7 males , 6 females , 290 of undetermined gender).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 15–22. Genitalia of
Brachyolus punctatus
. 15, penis, dorsal view; 16, aedeagus, lateral view; 17, male hemisternites 8 and spiculum gastrale, lateral view (muscles between hemisternite 8 and basal plate indicated); 18, male hemisternites 8 and spiculum gastrale with basal plate, ventral view; 19, female tergite 8, dorsal view; 20, ovipositor, dorsal view; 21, ovipositor and spermatheca, lateral view; 22, female sternite 8, ventral view. Scale bars = 0.5 mm; 15–18 at same scale; 19–22 at same scale.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 23. Distribution of
Brachyolus punctatus White.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. North Island, South Island: WO, BP, GB, TO, HB, RI, WI, WN, WA / SD, NN, KA / — ( Figure 23 ).

WO : Te Kuiti. BP : Lake Okataina; Rotorua; Tarukenga; Te Puke. GB : Hicks Bay; Lake Waikaremoana. TO : Pureora State Forest; Waipapa Reserve. HB : Puketitiri; Tangoio; Waipukurau. RI : Ohakune; Pohangina Valley. WI : Eketahuna; Pahiatua; Palmerston North; Woodville. WN : Karori; Kimberley Reserve; Masterton; Orongorongo Valley; Shannon; Wadestown. WA : Martinborough. SD : Chetwode Islands; D’Urville Island; Havelock; Marlborough Sounds; Maud Island; Mid Trios Islands; Motuara Island; Picton; Stephens Island; Te Kakaho. NN : Abel Tasman National Park; Collingwood; Kaiteriteri; Motueka; Nelson; Totaranui. KA : Puhi Puhi.
Elevational range. Label data: 180 m to 853 m ( X = ̄ 700 m , s = 202, n = 44). Georeferenced data: 7 m to 966 m ( X = ̄ 296 m , s = 279, n = 241).

Biology. Mahoe (
Melicytus ramiflorus
J. R. et G. Forst, 1776, Violaceae ) is a favoured host, with adults frequently found feeding on the foliage, sometimes in large numbers. Martin (2010) provides a description and photographs of the adult feeding damage. Specimens have also been taken in light traps, Malaise traps and litter samples. The larvae, and the host specificity thereof, are not known, but are predicted to also be associated with
Melicytus ramiflorus
.

Note on synonymy. Broun had only the original description of
B. punctatus
when he described his species ( Broun, 1893 ). The type specimens of
B. elegans
and
B. albescens
are a male and female respectively, and Broun appears to have used sexually dimorphic characters for differentiating the two. Both type specimens agree closely with the type series of
B. punctatus
. The type specimen of
I. breviusculus
is abraded and at a cursory glance appears very different from fully clothed specimens of
B. punctatus
. Upon inspection of structural features, however, it can be confidently placed in the same species. The type specimen of
B. viridescens
is a darker specimen than most other individuals of
B. punctatus
, but not sufficiently as to warrant being considered a separate species.
